He also digs into the various ways prompt injection does and doesn't work. The entire post is well worth your time but this part really jumped out at me:
When I searched aboutÂ creating an end for our sofa, PerplexityÂ hotlinkedÂ some photos from that post which resulting inÂ myÂ browser requesting them from my server. They're wastingÂ myÂ bandwidth to serve content toÂ theirÂ users. For many sites, there's a tangible cost associated with every byte served - they areÂ literallyÂ costing me money (albeit a small amount)
So not only can't they be trusted to follow the de facto rules about scraping websites, they're also hotlinking? Can they not spare any of the millions of dollars they've raised to actually cache the images they're serving up. "Might as well just use someone else's bandwidth". Dickheads. Ben offers a solution to this for nginx, replacing any request for an image from them with an image stating "perplexity just tried to steal my image and my bandwidth": location ~* \.(jpg|jpeg|png|gif|ico|bmp)$ { # Redirect image fetches from Perplexity AI if ($http_referer = "https://www.perplexity.ai/"){ rewrite (.*) path/to/image/perplexity_ai.jpg redirect; }} I don't host many images directly on this domain but rather put them on Bunny CDN so nginx won't help me here. Thankfully, Bunny has a way to block specific referrers. I don't get to do a funny image but this is close enough.
I know I said my last post would be my final word but this really pissed me off. So once again, fuck you Perplexity.

æ›´æ–°æ¨¡å—ã€Markdownã€Eleventyã€CSSã€æ’ä»¶ æ›´æ–°æ¨¡å—å’Œæ’ä»¶è®©ä½œè€…çš„åšå®¢æ›´æ–°æ›´æœ‰æ¡ç†ï¼ŒMarkdownè¯­æ³•ç®€å•æ˜“ç”¨ï¼Œé…åˆEleventyä½¿ç”¨æ›´æ–¹ä¾¿ï¼›CSSæ ·å¼è°ƒæ•´ä½¿æ’ä»¶è¾“å‡ºçš„æ›´æ–°æ¨¡å—é¢œè‰²æ­é…ç½‘ç«™é£æ ¼ç»Ÿä¸€ã€‚æ€»ç»“: æ›´æ–°æ¨¡å—æ’ä»¶è®©ä½œè€…åšå®¢æ›´æ–°æ›´æœ‰æ¡ç†ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨Markdownå’ŒEleventyæ›´ä¾¿æ·ï¼ŒCSSè°ƒæ•´è®©æ¨¡å—é¢œè‰²ä¸ç½‘ç«™é£æ ¼æ›´åŠ ç»Ÿä¸€ã€‚ I often have occasion to come back to a blog post and add some kind of update. Maybe I changed my mind or someone offered some new information I hadn't seen at the time of writing. Up until now I would just add updates willy-nilly; sometimes they'd be at the start, sometimes the end, sometimes in bold, sometimes not. What I wanted was something standard I could use and ideally with Markdown. GitHub has alerts (aka callouts) Markdown support where the syntax looks like this: > [!NOTE] > Highlights information that users should take into account, even when skimming.> [!TIP]> Optional information to help a user be more successful.> [!IMPORTANT] > Crucial information necessary for users to succeed.> [!WARNING] > Critical content demanding immediate user attention due to potential risks.> [!CAUTION]> Negative potential consequences of an action. These different types have different colors and icons on GitHub. I figured these would be perfect for my update blocks if I could just do: > [!NOTE] Update 2024-06-20> This is the update that has happened Thankfully someone had made a plugin to handle this with markdown-it, the renderer I use for this site: markdown-it-github-alerts. I installed the package and added it to my Eleventy config: let markdownLib = markdownIt(options) .use(require("markdown-it-footnote"))+ .use(require('markdown-it-github-alerts')) I also pulled in the CSS from the package into my CSS config and made a few tweaks: I've no intention of using anything other than the NOTE type so I wanted the colors to match my site rather than use GitHub's colors.
Finally I went and updated a bunch of old posts that had updates.
